titleInfo.title: High Dimensional Replicable Inference of Multiple Studies

mods:mods.abstract: Replicability is the cornerstone of scientific research. In this dissertation, we study replicability analysis of multiple studies from high throughput experiments, where tens of thousands of features are examined simultaneously. In the first chapter, we propose a statistical method, JUMP, for the high dimensional replicable analysis of two studies. The input is a high dimensional paired sequence of $p$-values from two studies and the test statistic is the maximum of $p$-values of the pair. JUMP uses four states of the $p$-value pairs to indicate whether they are null or non-null. Conditional on the hidden states, JUMP computes the cumulative distribution function of the maximum of $p$-values for each state to conservatively approximate the probability of rejection under the composite null of replicability. JUMP estimates unknown parameters and uses a step-up procedure to control the false discovery rate. By incorporating different states of composite null, JUMP achieves a substantial power gain over existing methods while controlling the false discovery rate. Analyzing two pairs of spatially resolved transcriptomic datasets, JUMP makes biological discoveries that otherwise cannot be obtained by using existing methods. In the second chapter, we study the replicability analysis of multiple studies accounting for dependence. Existing replicability analysis methods either ignore the dependence among features or impose strong modeling assumptions, producing overly conservative or overly liberal results. Based on $p$-values from two studies, we use a four-state hidden Markov model to capture the structure of local dependence. Our method effectively borrows information from different features and studies while accounting for dependence among features and heterogeneity across studies. We show that the proposed method has better power than competing methods while controlling the false discovery rate, both empirically and theoretically. Analyzing datasets from genome-wide association studies reveals new biological insights that otherwise cannot be obtained by using existing methods. In the third chapter, we focus on replicable analysis of more than two studies. Since the dimension of cross-study signal indicators grows exponentially with the number of studies, existing methods for replicability analysis of two studies are not scalable. we propose a hierarchical model to group cross-study signal indicators into a small number of clusters. Our procedure borrows information from different studies by jointly analyzing different clusters. Simulation studies show that our procedure controls the false discovery rate and has higher power than competing methods.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
dimensional reduction, false discovery rate, hidden Markov model, high dimensional inference, replicable analysis
Hongyuan Cao, Professor Directing Dissertation; Steven Lenhert, University Representative; Fred Huffer, Committee Member; Chao Huang, Committee Member.
